and quality of life - Society and culture</topcClas>         <topcClas>Equality and inequality - Social stratification and groupings</topcClas>         <topcClas>Use and provision of specific social services - Social welfare policy and systems</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p>The <i>Life Opportunities Survey</i> (LOS) is a new large scale longitudinal survey of disability in Great Britain. It is the first major ONS social survey to explore disability in terms of the social barriers to participation that people experience. The survey compares the experiences of disabled people with those of nondisabled people.<br> <br> <b>Background:</b><br> The last major survey of disability in Great Britain was the <i>Disability Follow-up to the 1996/97 Family Resources Survey</i> (available at the UK Data Archive under SN 4090). Prior to that were the Office of Population Censuses and Surveys (OPCS) national surveys of disability carried out during 1985-88 (available from the Archive under GN 33214). In 2005, the Department for Work and Pensions (DWP) sponsored a feasibility study which recommended that a new dedicated disability survey was required.<br> <br> The new survey was needed to meet the following long term information needs on experiences of disabled people living in Great Britain:<ul><li>dynamics of disability over time, including the factors associated with transitions and onsets of impairment</li><li>social participation by disabled people </li><li>up-to-date prevalence rates of impairments</li></ul>In 2007 the Office for Disability Issues (ODI) commissioned the ONS to develop a new longitudinal survey of disability.<br> <br> <b>Longitudinal design:</b><br> The LOS is a longitudinal survey. This means it will track the experiences of disabled people over time to assess transitions through key life stages, such as moving from childhood to adulthood or in and out of work.<br> <br> The longitudinal design enables three distinct groups to be followed over time:<ul><li>disabled group</li><li>comparison group of non-disabled people</li><li>a larger non-disabled group, monitored for the onset of impairment over time</li></ul>Respondents will be interviewed every 12 months, whether they are resident in the original household or have since moved. Following the baseline survey only the first two groups will be interviewed face-to-face. The third group will be monitored over time via a shorter telephone interview to check for the onset of an impairment. If any member of the household has experienced the onset of impairment, they will be invited to take part in a face to face interview.<br> <br> Further information about the LOS series is available from the <a href="http://www.ons.gov.uk/ons/guide-method/surveys/respondents/household/life-opportunities-survey/index.html" title ="Life Opportunities Survey">ONS LOS</a> web pages.<br> <br> <b>End User Licence and Special Licence LOS data:</b><br> Users should note that there are two versions of each LOS study. One is available under the standard End User Licence (EUL) agreement, and the other is a Special Licence (SL) version. The SL version contains geographic variables (Country, Government Office Region and Local Authority), deciles, age bands, a rural/urban indicator, and more information on household relationships, country of previous residence, medical conditions and occupations.<br> <br> The EUL version contains less detailed variables. For example, there is no spatial unit and age is top-coded at 80. Users are advised to first obtain the standard EUL version of the data to see if they are sufficient for their research requirements.<br> <br> The SL data have more restrictive access conditions than those made available under the standard EUL. Prospective users of the SL version will need to complete an extra application form and demonstrate to the data owners exactly why they need access to the additional variables in order to get permission to use that version. Therefore, users are strongly advised to order the standard version of the data. In order to help users choose the correct dataset, 'Special Licence Access' has been added to the dataset titles for the SL versions of the data.<br> </abstract>       <abstract>The main End User Licence version of the <i>Life Opportunities Survey: Waves 1-2, 2009-2012</i> is held under SN 6653.<br> <br> For the fourth edition (August/October 2014), data and documentation for Wave 2 have been added to the study. The Wave 2 data are contained within a combined longitudinal file containing data from both waves. The previous cross-sectional Wave 1 data file also remains available, as it contains variables that are not included on the longitudinal file. There is no equivalent cross-sectional Wave 2 data file.<br> </abstract>       <abstract><B>Main Topics</B>:<br>The LOS questionnaire is divided into two parts. <br> <br> The first part is the Integrated Household Survey (IHS) core module. The core module collects basic demographic information and other household information for all members of the household.<br> <br> The second part of the questionnaire is the LOS module. This module is administered to each adult in the household and they are asked questions about:<ul><li>education and training</li><li>employment</li><li>economic life and living standards</li><li>transport</li><li>leisure, social and cultural activities</li><li>social contact</li><li>housing</li><li>accessibility in the home</li><li>accessibility of public services</li><li>domestic life and social care</li><li>discrimination</li><li>crime</li><li>impairments and health conditions</li><li>disability as defined by the Disability Discrimination Act</li><li>income and benefits</li></ul>Information about impairments and health conditions of children aged 11 to 15 was collected by parental proxy.</abstract>       <sumDscr>         <collDate event="start" date="2009-06-01T00:00:00Z">June 2009</collDate>         <collDate event="end" date="2012-03-01T00:00:00Z">March 2012</collDate>         <nation>Great Britain</nation>         <geogUnit>Countries</geogUnit>         <geogUnit>Government Office Regions</geogUnit>         <geogUnit>Local Authority Districts</geogUnit>         <anlyUnit>Individuals</anlyUnit>         <universe>National</universe>         <universe>People aged 16 and over in private households in Great Britain. Parents or guardians will also be asked to provide some key data about children, aged 11 to 15. Children will be able to take part in a face-to-face interview when they reach age 16.</universe>         <dataKind>Numeric data</dataKind>         <dataKind> Individual (micro) level</dataKind>       </sumDscr>     </stdyInfo>     <method>       <dataColl>         <timeMeth>Longitudinal/panel/cohort</timeMeth>         <timeMeth>Respondents will be interviewed every 12 months.</timeMeth>         <sampProc>Multi-stage stratified random sample</sampProc>         <deviat>47,701 cases across Waves 1-2.</deviat>         <collMode>Face-to-face interview</collMode>         <sources />         <weight>Weighting used. See documentation for details.</weight>         <cleanOps>A</cleanOps>       </dataColl>     </method>     <dataAccs>       <setAvail>         <accsPlac>UK Data Service</accsPlac>       </setAvail>       <useStmt>         <specPerm>Special licence required</specPerm>         <restrctn>The depositor has specified that registration is required and standard conditions of use apply. The depositor may be informed about  usage.<br/>Additional special conditions of use also apply. See <a href=http://ukdataservice.ac.uk/get-data/how-to-access/conditions.aspx>terms and conditions of access</a> for further information.<br/><br/>In addition, the UK Data Service is required to request permission from the depositor prior to supplying the data.<br/>Available to UK applicants only.<br/><br/>Please note:<br/>Since these data pose a higher risk of disclosure than data made available under the standard End User Licence they have additional special conditions attached to them.  Any registered user requiring access to these data will have to be accredited by the UK Statistics Authority as an Approved Researcher.<br/><br/>To apply for accreditation a user will need to complete forms that will require: (i) evidence that he/she is a fit and proper person and details  about the purpose of the research; (ii) an online order for the data; (iii) a signed declaration that he/she understands the confidentiality obligations owed to those data including its physical security.<br/><br/>The evidence to be adduced will include previous research projects and publications. New users may need to provide the contact details of a senior  member of staff who can vouch for them. The research purpose form will ask for information about the intended use of the data, a justification for access and planned outputs.<br/><br/>Users who obtain access to these data are required to read and follow the guide,<a href='http://www.data-archive.ac.uk/media/132701/ukda171-ss-microdatahandling.pdf' >Microdata handling and security: guide to good practice</a>.<br/><br/>To apply for access, users should use the Download/Order link on this page and will be directed to the relevant forms as part of the ordering process.</restrctn>         <contact><a href=http://www.ukdataservice.ac.uk/help/get-in-touch.aspx>Get in touch</a></contact>       </useStmt>     </dataAccs>     <othrStdyMat>       <relPubl>   </relPubl>       <relPubl>Equality and Human Rights Commission (2013) <i>Standard of Living</i>, Measurement Framework Series Briefing Paper no.10, Manchester: Equality and Human Rights Commission. (2013) <i>Barriers to employment and unfair treatment at work: a quantitative analysis of disabled people's experiences</i>, Research Report no.88, Manchester: Equality and Human Rights Commission. Retrieved February 26, 2014 from <a href="http://www.equalityhumanrights.com/uploaded_files/barriers_and_unfair_treatment_final.pdf" title="Barriers to employment and unfair treatment at work: a quantitative analysis of disabled people's experiences">http://www.equalityhumanrights.com/uploaded_files/barriers_and_unfair_treatment_final.pdf</a><br></relPubl>       <othRefs>Language Of Study Description: English</othRefs>       <othRefs>Language Of Study Documentation: English</othRefs>     </othrStdyMat>   </stdyDscr> </codeBook>
